instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
Hi to all nice people

I have a very odd problem , on one 3332 board when I connect the charger I get a green light just for a sec and then off .
I connected it to the bench power supply to start measuring and the board magically turned on ???!!! 
I put it back and connected everything and on the normal charger it does the same thing green for one sec then off ... connected it to the bench power supply and the computer works completely normally , boots and everything ... noticed a small lag in the mouse movements though .
Took it out again and it repeats the same thing , works on bench supply but not on 85w charger , needless to say I tried 3 different chargers and the result is always the same green for a sec and nothing .
Tried it with everything disconnected and replaced the dc in board still the same .

Do you have some advice ? :)
Thanks a lot in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
Original (smart enough) Apple charger detects leakage on inpout circuit.
And it doesn't want to power up the board.
Usually caused by <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, or <DIODE>D6910</DIODE>.

Post exact value of <RESISTOR>R6912</RESISTOR>, measured onboard (ohm scale).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos 
both the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D6910</DIODE> "look" nice , no corrosion .... the <RESISTOR>R6912</RESISTOR> has 22 kOhms ...
Should I replace the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D6910</DIODE> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
<DIODE>D6910</DIODE> can be checked in diode mode.
I recommend you to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>.
I never saw both of them bad at same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
Just one small odd thing before I replace the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> ,  I just made some measurements before and I found something strange , the <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> measures just fine 62 kOhm <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> is 4k instead of 100k so I replaced that one with a proper 100k ....as soon as I soldered it on it was back on 4.3k grrrrr so I replaced it again and the second one was back on 4.3k..... 
Can I take the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> from a donor board or should it be new ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
That is 100% sign of leakage on <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, change it; <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> is OK, don't bother more with it.
You can pick it from scrap board, but check to have clean terminals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> strange problem :)
threads.message:
Thank you soooo much 2informaticos 

as always you are right , after replacing the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> everything back to working normal .
One more time thanks a lot , much appreciated , you can mark this thread as solved .

best regards
